image.altText: a camera and silhouette of a woman beside it

items.synopsis: The Queensland mother is facing the prospect of having nowhere to live after raising concerns about security cameras inside their rental property. She became so concerned she and her children left the property.

title.children: Sandy was told cameras in her rental home were inactive. Then she saw one light up

image.altText: Man sits in a camping chair with a fishing rod on the beach.

items.synopsis: A crime expert has told a coronial inquest the police officers who killed 24-year-old Luke Gilbert at Airlie Beach "were forced to take the action they did".

title.children: Inquest hears police 'forced' to shoot tradie dead at popular party precinct

image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: About 30 per cent of Australians live in rental accommodation with growing numbers in seats that helped secure government for Labor. But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week holds an important moment for housing policy — and renters are gaining influence

image.altText: Graphic of Australian Bank logos on houses including Commonwealth, ANZ, Westpac, and National.

items.synopsis: The big banks were offering cashback deals and competitive rates to grab their share of the refinancing boom, but the trend has reversed as margins start to come under pressure, leaving some borrowers trapped between a mortgage cliff and a mortgage prison.

title.children: Why the honeymoon is over — banks pull back on fight for new borrowers

image.altText: police tape down the side of a house

items.synopsis: Australian Defence Force personnel are travelling to Longreach to assess the object, found on a property once owned by late Queensland MP Vaughan Johnson.

title.children: Outback home under police guard after suspected World War II hand grenade found in yard

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: Australians with mental health issues are the fastest-growing group needing specialist homelessness services, according to a federal government report. Here, a Queensland woman reveals how she has come to be among them.

title.children: Being abused as a child left Phoebe Staggard with ongoing trauma. It has also left her homeless

image.altText: A French World Cup player looks to her left during a match.

items.synopsis: France defender Ève Périsset is set to mark Caitlin Foord in Saturday's Women's World Cup quarterfinal, while helping  her teammates plot how they will handle Chelsea colleague Sam Kerr.

title.children: The French star with the tips on how to handle Foord, Kerr in World Cup clash against Matildas

image.altText: A smiling woman with long, dark hair holds a shovel across her shoulder at a construction site. She wears a hard hat.

items.synopsis: Queensland Housing Minister Meaghan Scanlon says the government is aiming to maximise the use of space as the state continues to grapple with the housing shortage.

title.children: Minister tells critics to 'get out of the way' amid high-density housing push

image.altText: signs for a level crossing

items.synopsis: A level crossing north of Brisbane has taken the top spot for delaying traffic during the morning commute, with the boom gates blocking motorists for an average of about 90 minutes each weekday morning.

title.children: Government lists the worst 13 level crossings for holding up traffic in south-east Queensland

image.altText: Actors.

items.synopsis: In India, the Modi government is accused of waging a war on Bollywood and using it for party propaganda.

title.children: 'You have to suck up or shut up': The clampdown on Bollywood's unforgivable sin

image.altText: An Australian para-cyclist is congratulated after winning gold at the world championships.

items.synopsis: Just over a year out from the Paris Paralympic Games, Australia's Lauren Parker becomes a world champion in a second sport, striking hand-cycling gold after shining in the para-triathlon over recent years.

title.children: Aussie Parker wins world para-cycling title as Paralympics loom on the horizon

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander agencies, Voice to Parliament advocates and the prime minister have described a conspiracy theory on the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart as a misinformation campaign to avoid debating the facts.

title.children: Voice to Parliament conspiracy theory an attempt to create 'misinformation and division'

image.altText: A man in a hat and coat plays a guitar on stage.

items.synopsis: The singer died in Detroit after a short illness, according to his family.

title.children: Rodriguez, subject of Searching for Sugar Man documentary, dies at 81

image.altText: man stands with back to camera looking at streetscape

items.synopsis: Asylum seekers say they want to live with dignity and contribute to the country that has taken them in, but declining government assistance makes that impossible.

title.children: After fleeing Iraq, Ali was left shocked when he was told what he had to provide to get government aid

image.altText: A woman is working at her computer speaking on the phone and looking at a notebook she seems really busy

items.synopsis: The 3G network switch-off dates are looming. Telcos say Australia is ready for the transition to 4G and 5G, but some community members disagree.

title.children: Telcos claim Australians are ready for 3G switch off, but the network remains vital in the bush

image.altText: A stylised graphic of the ASX board with an up arrow.

items.synopsis: Wall Street indices fall overnight but the Australian share market looks set to buck the trend and rise in early trade.

title.children: Wall Street falls, Australian market set to defy downward lead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The big result out of the US overnight was Disney, which was a mixed bag. The bright spot was 13% revenue growth for its theme parks, products and experiences division. However, the company lamented some disappointing box office results for films including Elemental and the latest Indiana Jones adventure. It also reported another drop in subscriber numbers for Disney+ to 146.1 million, down 7.4%, mainly due to the loss of broadcasting rights for Indian Premier League cricket. The relevant Disney+ Hotstar product lost 24% of its users. Earnings per share was slightly higher on an adjusted basis, while revenue was a touch lower than typical forecasts. The broadcaster took $US2.65 billion in one-time write-downs and charges, which dragged it to a $US460 million net loss.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney loses subscribers after missing out on Indian cricket rights

Disney

13% revenue growth for its theme parks, products and experiences
division.
However, the company lamented some disappointing box office results for films including Elemental and the latest Indiana Jones adventure.
It also reported another
drop in subscriber numbers for Disney+ to 146.1 million, down 7.4%
, mainly due to the loss of broadcasting rights for Indian Premier League cricket.

Disney+ Hotstar
product lost 24% of its users.

, which dragged it to a $US460 million net loss.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, I'm joining you for a short while to take you through a couple of the company results that Dan flagged earlier. First up, AGL. It might be hard to believe that an electricity and gas company could possibly lose money given current power bills, but that's exactly what AGL did last year. It's reported a $1, 264 million net statutory loss for financial year 2023, which just ended on June 30. How did it lose so much money? There's two main reasons: It wrote down the value of its coal power plants by $680 million after deciding to close some of them earlier than previously planned. It lost $890 million from the value of various financial instruments, mostly futures contracts for electricity, after government intervention and market forces caused the wholesale price of power to drop dramatically late last year. AGL was stuck with contracts that were above the new market pricing. Excluding those write-downs, AGL's underlying net profit after tax was $281 million, up 25%. And if you think that still sounds small in a sector where retail prices have just jumped by around 20-30%, then don't worry, AGL is about to make up for it. It has reiterated its forecasts for an underlying net profit of between $580 and $780 million for the current 2024 financial year. That is somewhere between double and nearly triple this year's profit. As a 'gentailer' — a power generator who also retails to customers — AGL is benefitting from "sustained periods of higher wholesale electricity pricing" and expected improved power plant availability, with less forced outages. However, it says inflation, difficulty collecting debts of some customers and increased maintenance spend will cap profit growth. This blog covered AGL's June announcement about its updated profit forecasts, below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy company AGL posts $1.26 billion loss

featuredLink.title: AGL set to double profit as energy prices soar, ASX up, Wall Street rallies, Europe lifts rates — as it happened

children.content: Good morning, I'm joining you for a short while to take you through a couple of the company results that Dan flagged earlier.
First up,
AGL
It might be hard to believe that an electricity and gas company could possibly lose money given current power bills, but that's exactly what AGL did last year.
It's reported
a $1, 264 million net statutory loss
for financial year 2023, which just ended on June 30.
How did it lose so much money? There's two main reasons:
It
wrote down the value of its coal power plants by $680 million
after deciding to close some of them earlier than previously planned.
It
lost $890 million from the value of various financial instruments

, mostly futures contracts for electricity, after government intervention and market forces caused the wholesale price of power to drop dramatically late last year. AGL was stuck with contracts that were above the new market pricing.
Excluding those write-downs,
AGL's underlying net profit after tax was $281 million, up 25%
And if you think that still sounds small in a sector where retail prices have just jumped by around 20-30%, then don't worry, AGL is about to make up for it.
It has reiterated its
forecasts for an underlying net profit of between $580 and $780 million for the current 2024 financial year
That is somewhere between double and nearly triple this year's profit.

As a 'gentailer' — a power generator who also retails to customers — AGL is benefitting from "sustained periods of higher wholesale electricity pricing" and expected improved power plant availability, with less forced outages.
However, it says inflation, difficulty collecting debts of some customers and increased maintenance spend will cap profit growth.
This blog covered AGL's June announcement about its updated profit forecasts, below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business team here to kick off the day on our markets blog. The ASX 200 is set to lift (a little) despite losses on the key US indices. The Dow Jones was down -0.5% in trading, the broader S & P 500 -0.7% and the tech-focused Nasdaq -1.2%. The Sydney Futures Exchange sees the ASX 200 moderately higher when trading opens later this morning, up four points or +0.006% to 7,279 points. In March we found out that wages had lifted 3.7% in the year (well below inflation) through the Wage Price Index (WPI). That meant a cut to "real wages" — the income you have once you include what inflation has eroded from your purchasing power. There's new weekly payroll jobs figures out today, ahead of new WPI data on Tuesday. It'll give us a little look in to what's happening to pay packets …
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to rise despite Wall Street losses

children.content: Good morning,
Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business team here to kick off the day on our markets blog.
The ASX 200 is set to lift (a little) despite losses on the key US indices.
The Dow Jones was down -0.5% in trading, the broader S
P 500 -0.7% and the tech-focused Nasdaq -1.2%.
The Sydney Futures Exchange sees the ASX 200 moderately higher when trading opens later this morning, up four points or +0.006% to 7,279 points.
In March we found out that wages had lifted 3.7% in the year (well below inflation) through the Wage Price Index (WPI).
That meant a cut to "real wages" — the income you have once you include what inflation has eroded from your purchasing power.
There's new weekly payroll jobs figures out today, ahead of
new WPI data on Tuesday. It'll give us a little look in to what's happening to pay packets …
